Sarasota County has entrusted the Nathan Benderson Park Conservancy with the complete day-to-day care of this 550-acre community asset. As the stewards of the Park, the Conservancy tends to the complex maintenance, visitor services, event management, outreach programs and so much more. Vision Nathan Benderson Park Conservancy’s vision of Nathan Benderson Park is to serve as a global, innovative, and premier destination that welcomes and connects people, while fostering a healthy, sustainable and safe environment. Core Values EXCEED EXPECTATIONS: To go from ordinary to extraordinary. EMBRACE CHANGE: Unlimited thinking creates unlimited possibilities. CUSTOMER SATISFACTION: It is all about you. VARIETY OF OPPORTUNITIES: Something for everyone. HEALTH & WELLNESS: Provide and promote healthy lifestyle opportunities for our staff and community. INTEGRITY: Do everything personally and professionally with the highest sense of ethical values. VALUE PEOPLE: Enable individuals to learn their value to the community through recreational opportunities. Our staff is our greatest resource and investment for success. EDUCATE: Help the members of our community learn the importance of living a healthy lifestyle through the assistance of recreational programs. Commitment to Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Nathan Benderson Park is a community park and world-class event facility which welcomes and is enjoyed by hundreds of thousands of individuals from throughout the world. These individuals represent a diversity of backgrounds, identities and abilities. As stewards of the park, Nathan Benderson Park Conservancy is committed to creating and, continuously improving, an inclusive and equitable environment in which all visitors and staff members feel safe, respected and valued – regardless of any aspect of one’s identity, including but not limited to race, ethnicity, national origin, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, religion, socioeconomic status, ability or age. We strive to provide opportunities and access to all who wish to enjoy the Park. Sport makes Nathan Benderson Park unique and it is one of the major drivers of the Conservancy’s mission. We recognize, celebrate and embrace the opportunity sport provides to unite a diversity of individuals in a common interest. Striving to have a board and staff representative of a diversity of identities, the Conservancy celebrates our place in a diverse global community.  We embrace and recognize that representation and diversity of thought and perspective makes us stronger and best able to serve our global community. Each individual you meet here works tirelessly behind the scenes to ensure that your experience at our park is nothing short of memorable. From the meticulous maintenance of our grounds to the coordination of spectacular events and community programs, our staff’s dedication truly makes Nathan Benderson Park a gem of the Sarasota-Bradenton region. Let’s introduce you to the team that makes it all possible. Bruce C. Led by certified Zumba instructor Yael Campbell, these classes offer a fun, full-body workout. Enjoy easy-to-follow dance moves set to lively Latin music that makes exercise feel like a dance party! Learn more about Zumba classes with Yael Campbell Join Yael’s Zumba Facebook Group Camp Gladiator Get a taste of bootcamp with Camp Gladiator. This four-week fitness program is led by certified personal trainers and features a 60-minute, total-body outdoor workout. Combining cardio and strength training, Camp Gladiator offers a fresh approach to fitness. Learn More & Register Here Schedule at NBP Club Pilates Pilates by the Lake at Nathan Benderson Park – Free! Come join us for a relaxing Pilates session by the lake at Nathan Benderson Park ! Take in the serene views of the water while getting a great workout in. This in-person event is perfect for all fitness levels, whether you’re a beginner or a seasoned pro. Bring a mat, some water, and get ready to strengthen your core and improve your flexibility in this beautiful outdoor setting. Don’t miss out! Perfect for ages 15+. You can sign up in advance on eventbrite or just show up! For a list of class days and times, please visit our Events calendar . The meeting will be held via Teams. Please contact Karen Burkett at kburkett@nathanbendersonpark.org or at 941-358-7275, ext. 5807, to receive information on how to join the meeting. General business will include Board governance and other matters as may come before the Board, followed by an Executive Session. All are welcome to attend. The Nathan Benderson Park Conservancy, Inc. does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, religion, age, marital status or disability status in employment or in the provision of services. According to Section 286.0105, Florida Statutes, any person desiring to appeal any decision made by the Board of the Nathan Benderson Park Conservancy, Inc. with respect to any matter considered at the meeting will need a record of the proceedings, and for such purposes may need to ensure that a verbatim record of the proceedings is made, which includes the testimony and evidence upon which the appeal is to be based. Op-Ed You are viewing: The Suncoast Post > Events > Nathan Benderson Park Awarded 2022-23 US Rowing Masters National Championships Search Nathan Benderson Park Awarded 2022-23 US Rowing Masters National Championships April 14, 2022 | Suncoast Post Staff | Events For the first time in nearly a decade, the nation’s best masters rowers will once again convene under the Florida sun. The 2022 and 2023 US Rowing Masters National Championships will be held at Nathan Benderson Park.  Nathan Benderson Park Conservancy will play host, with support from Visit Sarasota County. This year’s regatta will be Aug. 11-14, while next year’s regatta will be Aug. 10-13, 2023. The regattas will feature racing in more than 200 masters categories. “This recent awarding of the USRowing Masters Nationals is a telling tale of the benefits and success of Nathan Benderson Park and its operator, the Nathan Benderson Park Conservancy,” said Stephen V. Rodriguez, the Conservancy’s chief operating officer, and interim chief executive officer. “Being awarded a national championship event just four months away from the event date shows the park’s ability to be ready at a moment’s notice to take on new opportunities for the benefit of our community.” He said it’s a testament to “ the hard work of the Conservancy staff and the trust it has earned from event rights holders to be able to deliver. ” Rodriguez pointed to the park’s growing masters program, the NBP Community Rowing Club, and said its athletes, along with other masters programs in the community, will benefit by having the event in their backyard. “This is a benefit that is often overlooked when we announce that we are hosting events,” he said. “It isn’t just about bringing visitors to our area. It’s also about connecting our area athletes to competitive opportunities in their backyard.” NBP Programs and Aquatics Manager Miriam Ward said the regatta will be a shot in the arm. “I believe that Nathan Benderson Park having the opportunity to host USRowing Masters Nationals will be transformational for the NBP Community Rowing Club,” she said. “As the masters team grows and flourishes with a community-driven focus, it will be a chance to host the entire country’s fellow masters at our home base, welcoming everyone with open arms to show them what the NBP Community Rowing Club is all about.” Rowers obtain masters status in the year of their 21st birthday, according to USRowing. They compete in distinct age group classifications. When the USRowing Masters Nationals were at NBP in 2013, the venue was in its infancy, said Sarah McAuliffe, USRowing’s director of event planning and services. “We’re looking forward to hosting our masters athletes in Sarasota the next two years,” she said. “Since 2013, Sarasota has hosted several national championships and World Rowing events, including the highly-successful World Rowing Masters Regatta in 2018. We hope that all of our masters rowers will take advantage of the opportunity to race at this world-class venue.” The nation’s premier rowing venue, Nathan Benderson Park has hosted numerous national rowing events including the 2019 USRowing Youth National Championships and 2021 USRowing Youth National Regatta. The venue also has hosted premier international and trials events including the 2017 World Rowing Championships, 2018 World Rowing Masters Regatta and 2019 World Rowing Under 23 Championships, as well as the 2016 and 2020 U.S. Olympic Team Trials – Rowing. The venue is slated to host the 2022 USRowing Youth National Championships this June and the 2022 USRowing Southeast Regional Championships and NCAA Women’s Rowing Championships for Divisions I, II and III in May. In addition to racing, rowers will be able to soak up the sun along Sarasota’s white-sand beaches or treat themselves to diverse dining, enriching arts and culture, shopping districts of all sorts, and natural Florida fun. “We are so thrilled to welcome the masters rowing community back to Sarasota County this summer and next,” said Virginia Haley, Visit Sarasota County president. “Our local hospitality partners always enjoy hosting masters athletes, and we look forward to working with them to provide a few special programs for attendees to experience all that Sarasota has to offer.” About USRowing: USRowing is a nonprofit organization recognized by the U.S. Olympic Committee as the governing body for the sport of rowing in the United States. USRowing has 83,000 individual members and 1,350 member organizations, offering rowing programs for all. About Nathan Benderson Park Conservancy: The Nathan Benderson Park Conservancy is a not-for-profit 501c3 business created to manage Nathan Benderson Park (NBP), a community/public asset, and world-class, multi-use sports venue. Our mission is to improve the quality of life for our community and be an economic generator for our region. The Conservancy’s primary purpose is to develop and promote NBP as a world-class event center, team training site, and Sarasota County park, while providing outreach programs through recreation, safety training, education, and volunteering as a service to our community. For more information, go to Nathan Benderson Park . About Visit Sarasota County: Visit Sarasota County leads and supports the tourism industry in Sarasota County by providing the highest quality, and most innovative, marketing programs and promotions to ensure the continued growth of tourism and travel from visitors around the world. It is the mission of VSC is to make Sarasota County the must experience destination on Florida’s Gulf Coast. To learn more, visit the website . Nathan Benderson Park names new CEO News Sports Ticket Lifestyle Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals SARASOTA Nathan Benderson Park names new CEO Laura Finaldi lfinaldi@heraldtribune.com There’s a management shakeup going on at Nathan Benderson Park that indicates leadership is looking to the future. The nonprofit that runs the park, the Suncoast Aquatic Nature Center Associates Inc., has named Tomas Herrera-Mishler as its new CEO. Herrera-Mishler arrives in Sarasota from San Diego, where he was president and CEO of the 1,200-acre Balboa Park Conservancy for five years. The 600-acre Nathan Benderson Park sits just west of North Cattlemen Road and Interstate 75 in Sarasota. It features a 2,000-meter sprint rowing course and a regatta center. Current CEO Stephen Rodriguez will move into the chief operating officer role, focusing on day-to-day operations. Ronald Shapo, chairman of the SANCA board, said that the park is entering a new phase of growth and has to take the opportunity to capitalize on its potential. Last year, the park held 131 events, welcoming more than 150,000 participants. The park generated about $34.8 million in economic impact in its 2018-19 fiscal year. “We are very pleased that Tomas has agreed to assume the mantle of leadership of the park as we move forward,” Shapo said. “His unique background and skill set will be invaluable in helping us achieve our goals and maximize our future growth in a fiscally responsible and environmentally sensitive manner.” In his role at Balboa Park, Herrera-Mishler managed a $4.3 million operating budget and a staff of 26. The park includes the San Diego Zoo, 17 museum and 20 public gardens. Before that, his vast resume includes a stint as CEO and president of the Buffalo Olmsted Parks Conservancy in Buffalo, New York, where he helped to secure almost $30 million in capital improvement projects toward the implementation of the system’s master plan. Read more stories by Laura Finaldi He has also worked as the executive director of the Awbury Arboretum in Philadelphia, Airlie Gardens in Wilmington, North Carolina, and the Massachusetts Horticultural Society in Boston. A member of the World Urban Parks Organization and the City Parks Alliance, Herrera-Mishler has also served as co-chair of the American Society of Landscape Architects Parks and Recreation Professional Practice Group, and on many other boards. He started his career in Florida as a registered landscape architect at Wallace Roberts Todd in Coral Gables, where his projects included the master plans for the Ringling Museum and the Civic Center in Sarasota. “Nathan Benderson Park is a special community asset in Sarasota and an internationally recognized rowing facility. I am excited to be leading this venture to build and operate the finest park in our region, serving guests and residents through high-quality recreational amenities, fitness, events and programs in a beautiful park setting,” Herrera-Mishler said in a statement. Traditionally, fundraising for Nathan Benderson Park has been handled by the Nathan Benderson Community Park Foundation, Rodriguez said. Shapo said that SANCA took on some of its own fundraising responsibilities last year outside of the foundation, but that the the foundation also does fundraising work. One of Herrera-Mishler’s major responsibilities will be community outreach, Shapo said. “It is clear that the community as a whole doesn’t know a lot about the park, if anything, in many instances,” he said. “It’s very important that we have a representative, Tomas, as the face of the park, to begin engaging with the community and to have active outreach within the community. As a hopefully logical byproduct of that, we hope that that will also be significant in helping us with regards to fundraising, which we will be seeking to do, in a more active way which was not in our role previously.” Hiring someone of Herrera-Mishler’s caliber wasn’t within SANCA’s budget, Shapo said, so the foundation as well as a search committee began a private fundraising effort to put together the amount they would need to attract such a person. They secured about $200,000 before the CEO search began several months ago. Shapo did not disclose who contributed to the fund, only saying it was a group of people. In transitioning to chief operating officer, Rodriguez said the function of his job won’t change that much. His pay also isn’t changing, he said. “My day-to-day role in the organization really doesn’t change at all from what I do every day — operating the park, promoting the park, seeking events and creating new programs,” he said. “I do want to say we have an amazing team too. We have a great staff that works hard.” Rodriguez said the switch has been in the works for a while and makes sense for the future of the park. “When you look at the skill set Tomas has, he comes from the conservancy side and park development and design. My background has always been sports tourism events,” he said. “I think we have complementing skill sets and we should be a great team.” Careers Staff Directory Accessibility Sitemap Legals Public notice certification Our Ethical Principles USA TODAY Network Style Guide Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Advertiser Acceptance Policy Terms of Service Privacy Policy California Notice at Collection Your Privacy Choices Contact Us Support Local Business Advertise Your Business Promote your Event Licensing & Reprints Public Notices Help Center Subscriber Guide Manage Account Give Feedback Submit Community News Subscribe Today Newsletters Facebook X Instagram eNewspaper Archives Jobs Real Estate Classifieds Shopping 10BEST LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions © 2025 www.heraldtribune.com. Nathan Benderson Park gets new CEO News Sports Ticket Lifestyle Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals ROWING Nathan Benderson Park gets new CEO Florida Sports Foundation executive is second new leader there in less than a year Terry Galvin terry.galvin@heraldtribune.com SARASOTA COUNTY — The nonprofit that operates Nathan Benderson Park has its second new president and CEO in less than a year. The board of directors of the Suncoast Aquatic Nature Center Associates said Wednesday afternoon that it had appointed Florida Sports Foundation executive Stephen V. Rodriguez to lead SANCA starting in August. The change comes two months before the park holds the area's biggest international sporting event, the World Rowing Championships, which are expected to attract 40,000 people to the park from Sept. 24 to Oct. 1. In May, after holding the job for nine months, CEO Bob Sullivan had told the board and Sarasota County, which owns the park, that he intended to leave at the end of the year. Rodriguez, 44, has more than 25 years of event marketing and management experience and more than 13 years of professional experience in the sports industry. Looking for a free mini puzzle? Play the USA TODAY Quick Cross now. SANCA chairman Bill Robinson said Rodriguez is right for the job and gave a nod to the work of Sullivan and the organization's first CEO, Paul Blackketter. “Stephen’s expertise in sports promotion combined with his background marketing the state of Florida as a premier sports destination meshes impeccably with SANCA’s mission,” Robinson said. “Paul created NBP, Bob has maintained it, and we are confident Stephen will propel it in into the future!” A graduate of the University of Florida, Rodriguez spent 18 years at the Florida Sports Foundation, where he had been senior vice president since 2010. The foundation is a non-profit corporation that is the sports industry development division of Enterprise Florida Inc., which works to attract jobs and businesses to the state. At the foundation, Rodriguez was responsible for administration, event planning, finance, fundraising, government relations, program management, tourism and economic development. He is also the longest-standing director of the statewide Sunshine State Games and the Florida Senior Games. Before joining the foundation, he worked for the Palm Beach County Sports Commission and Sports Institute, where he ran the county's Unified Youth Sports Program and the Lou Groza Collegiate Place Kicker compeition. He also managed events such as the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics Spring Championship Games. Before Palm Beach, he was the office manager and membership chairman of the USA Track & Field/Florida Association. The Gainesville native is living in Palm Harbor and planning to move to Manatee County, a SANCA spokeswoman said. “Nathan Benderson Park has established itself as a world renowned rowing center and versatile county park that hosts numerous events for the entire community to enjoy.  I couldn’t be more excited to bring my experience and passion for the entire area to SANCA,” Rodriguez said in a statement. “I look forward to working with the SANCA staff and board, as well as the Sarasota County government, in taking NBP to the world stage, beginning with the World Rowing Championships in September, NCAA Women’s Rowing Championships in 2018, and 2018 World Rowing Masters Regatta.” Careers Staff Directory Accessibility Sitemap Legals Public notice certification Our Ethical Principles USA TODAY Network Style Guide Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Advertiser Acceptance Policy Terms of Service Privacy Policy California Notice at Collection Your Privacy Choices Contact Us Support Local Business Advertise Your Business Promote your Event Licensing & Reprints Public Notices Help Center Subscriber Guide Manage Account Give Feedback Submit Community News Subscribe Today Newsletters Facebook X Instagram eNewspaper Archives Jobs Real Estate Classifieds Shopping 10BEST LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions © 2025 www.heraldtribune.com. There is no admission to enter the park. During special events, such as rowing regattas and Fireworks on the Lake, there is special pricing to park. Please check these events on our calendar for more information. Are dogs allowed? Yes, dogs are welcome on a six-foot leash. Please clean up after your pet. What other wildlife can you find at the park? At the park you can find plenty of wildlife.  Birds are plentiful. Visit the Sarasota Audubon Society to learn more about birds that can be spotted. Fish such as crappie, bass and blue gill are plentiful in the lake. There is also wildlife to watch out for such as snakes and alligators. If you spot an alligator, please let us know by emailing us at info@nathanbendersonpark.org or calling 941-358-7275. Can I rent the park for a 5K walk, run, regatta or private party? Yes, we would love to host your 5K walk, run, or regatta! We also offer rental space in our Benderson Family Finish Tower and our Pavilion for private events. Please reach out to us booking@nathanbendersonpark.org for more information, or submit your event inquiry here to check date availability and rates. Can I swim in the lake? Swimming in the lake is only allowed during special events such as sanctioned triathlons and swimming events. Are kayaks and standup paddleboards permitted on the lake? Yes, you are permitted to bring in a kayak or SUP and enjoy the lake. You can launch from the beach area. Please note that the lake may be closed due to a special event or practice. Please check our events calendar and be mindful of others out on the water. What is the average temperature of the lake? March – October:   76 degrees October – March:   65 degrees Are there bathrooms? Yes, we have several public bathrooms conveniently located throughout the park. Can I use electric motors on a boat in the lake? No. Powered boats are not permitted unless for official park operations or during training and special events. Where are park offices located? We have moved! Our new offices are located in the Benderson Family Finish Tower and open Monday-Friday from 8:30am-4:00pm. Offices are closed on Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Year’s Day, MLK Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day & Labor Day. Offices may close early on the eve of holidays or due to weather-related emergencies. To check if the office is open, please call our main number at 941-358-7275. Third Floor:  Event & Program Offices Fourth Floor:  Administrative Offices   (Accounting, Sales, Marketing, Operations) Staff Contact list Our Facilities office and the Sarasota Crew office are located in the gray trailer next to the launch and recovery platforms. Here you can obtain keys to reserved launch boats and contracted repair service providers can report to meet with our facilities manager. What are the hours of the park? The park is open 6am-6pm from mid-November to mid-March and 6am-8pm from mid-March to mid-November. The change to the hours coincides with daylight savings time each year. What should I do if I accidentally stay at the park past closing and the gates are locked? We have security at the park after hours. They are actively patrolling all areas both on foot and in their vehicles. You may flag them down or can contact the company, OSA security, via their Site Lead at 941-896-1367.  You may also call to report an after hours safety concern. Should you have an emergency or witness an emergency situation in or around the park, please call 911. Do you have a lost & found? Yes, please contact us at info@nathanbendersonpark.org or call 941-358-7275 to inquire about lost and found items, or bring them to the staff offices on the 4th Floor of the Finish Tower between 8:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday.  Looking for a lost item? You can stop by the office, email us or message us on Facebook & Instagram. Can I fish at the Park? Yes, fishing is allowed at the park but only in designated areas. Fishing is permitted off the shores of the west bank, south shore and east bank. Fishing is not allowed on the Island and any of the docks for the safety of the rowers and paddlers. Can I cook food in the park? No. Open fires or cooking of food are prohibited. Pricing Log in Sign up 3 minute read Nathan Benderson Park 13 from Events and Activities Guide - June-Dec. 2021 by jtenbusch Next Article Venice Area Audubon Rookery NATHAN BENDERSON PARK 5851 Nathan Benderson Circle, Sarasota Advertisement This park offers indoor and outdoor reservable space. To reserve space or equipment, visit NathanBendersonPark.org, contact info@sanca.us or call 941-358-7275. ACTIVITIES NBP REC DAYS! Year-round / All ages / Fee: $10 per person, $5 per adult with accompanying child, Free for children 6 and younger, Family maximum $35 / Regatta Island / Schedule is available at nathabendersonpark.org/recdays / 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. It’s a great way to experience NBP, family-style! Participants will have the opportunity to try stand-up paddleboarding, kayaking, canoes, fishing and more! (Wednesday NBP Rec Days! are ideal for homeschool and virtual students!) DRAGON BOAT PADDLING: CLASSES AND TEAMS Year‐round / Ages: 12 and older / Fee: Classes: $80; Private lessons: $55‐110 / Regatta Island / Days and times vary Learn the fundamentals of paddling. Participants can expect to learn the stroke basics as well as on-the-water experience in the boat. The paddling class is the prerequisite for joining the community team. Community team paddling will consist of practicing three days a week and competing in tournaments. For details, call 941‐358‐7275 or email programs@sanca.us. EQUIPMENT RENTALS Year‐round / All ages (under 18 must be accompanied by an adult) / Fee: Starting at $15 per day, package pricing also available / Regatta Island / Daily Pedal pontoon boat, single and double sit-on-top kayaks, and stand-up paddleboard rentals. For more information or to reserve equipment, visit nathanbendersonpark.org, email programs@sanca.us or call 941358-7275. FITNESS CLASSES Year-round / All ages / Fee: Varies / Location, days and times vary Throughout the year, NBP offers a variety of fitness groups such as Camp Gladiator and Flex Fitness, and an array of classes from ChiWalking to Zumba. For all the latest additions and offerings, visit nathanbendersonpark.org LEARN TO ROW: CLASSES AND PRIVATE LESSONS Year‐round / Ages: 8 and older / Fee: Classes: $120; Private lessons: $55‐110 / Regatta Island / Days and times vary Learn to Row 101 focuses on the fundamentals of sculling, which is rowing with two oars. Individuals will be taken step-by-step through nomenclature, safety maneuvers and independent boat handling skills. The eight‐hour course will provide you with the skill set to row a single scull. For details, call 941-358-7275 or email programs@sanca.us. TEAM BUILDING SPECIAL EVENTS 2021 U.S. DRAGON BOAT FEDERATION CLUB CREW NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIPS Oct. 1-3 / All ages / Fee: Varies / Regatta Island / Friday-Sunday, varying times This championship event is held biennially in odd years at locations around the United States. Crews from clubs nationwide compete for berths in each division/class allotted to the United States for the chance to compete at the International Dragon Boat Federation Club Crew World Championships. NBP TRICK OR TREAT ON THE LAKE Oct. 26 / All ages / Fee: Free / Event Garden and Westbank / Tuesday, varying times Safe, family-friendly trick or treat event for all ages! There’ll be movies on the big screen, games, and vendors on site. FLORIDA TURKEY TROT Thanksgiving Morning / All ages / Fee: Varies / Regatta Island / Thursday, varying times The Florida Turkey Trot is the final of three races in the Holiday Race Challenge. This race will be a part of your Thanksgiving tradition as you enjoy the festivities. Race finishers cross the finish line after running the floating final mile over the lake and will be awarded a tasty treat to commence their Thanksgiving feast. FINISH TOWER RENTAL The finish tower is now available to host your next event! This newly constructed building has a rooftop terrace and indoor space available for: • Weddings • Private parties • Conferences • Banquets • Meetings • Corporate retreats Visit NathanBendersonPark.org or call 941-358-7275. Year-round / All ages / Fee: Varies / Location, days and times vary Let NBP lead your team-building event. Whether you are corporate, family, youth or adults, we can tailor the experience to meet specific needs of your group. Call 941-358-7275 or email programs@sanca.us. PAVILION AT THE EVENT GARDEN Are you interested in hosting a birthday party at the playground at Nathan Benderson Park? You can rent the pavilion adjacent to the playground for a memorable party. Visit NathanBendersonPark.org or call 941-358-7275. Board of Directors | Nathan Benderson Park Follow Follow Follow Volunteer Visit General Info Amenities Area Attractions FAQs Events Calendar Signature Events Trick or Treat on the Lake Benderson Chase Turkey Trot Fireworks On The Lake On Land On Water Venue Rentals Venue Rentals Festivals & Races Catering Partners Become a Vendor Marketplace & Experience Partners Food & Beverage Vendors Training Camps & Programs NBP Summer Adventure Camps Rowing Paddling Memberships Sarasota Model Yacht Club Fitness & Recreation Fitness Classes Top Activities About Us Leadership Board of Directors Staff Mission, Vision & Values History Careers Volunteer Donate Menu Close M Visit General Info Amenities Area Attractions FAQs Events Calendar Signature Events Trick or Treat on the Lake Benderson Chase Turkey Trot Fireworks On The Lake On Land On Water Venue Rentals Venue Rentals Festivals & Races Catering Partners Become a Vendor Marketplace & Experience Partners Food & Beverage Vendors Training Camps & Programs NBP Summer Adventure Camps Rowing Paddling Memberships Sarasota Model Yacht Club Fitness & Recreation Fitness Classes Top Activities About Us Leadership Board of Directors Staff Mission, Vision & Values History Careers Volunteer Donate Board of Directors Steering the Course: Meet Our Board of Directors At the helm of Nathan Benderson Park’s vision and initiatives is our dedicated Board of Directors. Comprising local leaders who share a passion for community growth and recreational prosperity, our board plays an instrumental role in guiding the park’s operations, projects, and strategic direction. Their commitment to making Nathan Benderson Park a world-class facility resonates through every inch of our verdant landscapes and inviting waters. Michael Taaffe, J.D. Chairman of the Board Taaffe is a preeminent trial attorney and director of Shumaker’s Broker-Dealer and Data Breach Groups. He has a lifelong involvement with rowing, including service as a founding member and coach of Sarasota Crew, which he led to several regional, state and national championships. Joanne Fava, D.C. Secretary Fava has overseen the medical side of the park since the beginning. She also helms a successful sports medicine practice.In 2024, she received the Volunteer of the Year Leadership Award and was award the SCOTY award by the American Chiropractic Board of Sports Medicine. Curtis Jordan Chairman Elect Jordan has more than 30 years of experience as an elite international and intercollegiate coach, most recently with USRowing. Jordan coached the U.S. men’s coxed four in 1988 and 1992, the men’s four and bronze-medal lightweight four in 1996, and the lightweight men’s four in 2000. Ron Cutsinger Director Cutsinger, a Sarasota County commissioner, has been a financial advisor and is the owner and managing director of Waypoint Wealth Management, a full-service financial services firm, for nearly 30 years. He is an active water sports enthusiast. Linda De Mello Director Linda’s career is distinguished by her leadership of complex, dynamic, and diverse organizations and communities in the fields of healthcare, career and workforce development, and higher education.  Linda recently served as the Manager of the Cross College Alliance (CCA), a remarkable 21st Century partnership of five universities and colleges in Sarasota Manatee committed to leveraging the assets of each institution to collaboratively enhance the learning opportunities for all students, the excellence of the region’s workforce, and the quality of life available to all members of the community. Molly Jackson Director Jackson serves on the board of The Gulf Coast CEO Forum, and served on the board for Girls Inc. for the last 6 years. She often shares her talent and expertise from her retail banking/finance where she served as a vice president for a premier private banking operation, extensive retailing experience, and omni-channel marketing perspective to not only help grow and expand their retail businesses but to also support the community and many non-profit organizations. Louis Kosiba Director Louis Kosiba’s experience includes work with the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund (1988-2017) Manager Field Services (1988-1990), General Counsel (1990-2001), Executive Director (2001-2017), Teacher’s Retirement System (1983-1988) General Counsel Florida Commitment, 2017 Retired and moved to Lakewood Ranch, 2018 Co-Treasurer for “Vote Yes For The Legacy Trail Extension”, a political action committee ( Sarasota County), 2019 President of The Friends of The Legacy Trail, 2020 Treasurer for “ Vote Yes for Water and Land”, a political action committee ( Manatee County ), 2020 Campaign Steering Committee member for Wildlife Center of Southwest Florida. Jay Riley Director Riley is the Senior Director of Corporate Partnerships and External Affairs for the Office of External Affairs and Government Relations, University of South Florida Sarasota-Manatee; works with current and potential partners across all USF campuses to strategically identify and access the institution’s vast resources. He works closely with students, faculty and staff to effectively manage mutually beneficial partnerships between the university and stakeholders. Ryan Thompson Director Thompson is a Sarasota native who has ties to NBP since inception having participated in the first unofficial race on the unimproved excavation pit in the early 2000s as a member of Sarasota Scullers Youth Rowing Program. Thompson is a Vice President and Shareholder at J.L. Bainbridge – Family Wealth Advisors and is board member at multiple local nonprofits. Welcome to Nathan Benderson Park—your outdoor location to row, paddle, walk, run, play, relax and celebrate. The many ways to experience Nathan Benderson Park are as diverse and worthwhile as the community it calls home. See Park Map Accommodations Visiting from out of town? Book your stay through our travel partner, Pellucid Travel to enjoy exclusive room rates at a nearby hotel. Click here to reserve your stay today! Hours Open Daily Monday to Sunday Mid-March through Mid-October 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. (Closes later due to Daylight Savings) Mid-October through Mid-March 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. (Closes early due to Daylight Savings) Location 5851 Nathan Benderson Park Circle Sarasota, FL 34235 Getting Here From the north, situated just west of Interstate 75, on the border of Manatee County, the park can be accessed by North Cattlemen Road and Honore Avenue. From the south, take Fruitville Road to N. Cattlemen or Honore Avenue. From the north take University Parkway to N. Cattleman or Honore Avenue. The community park is also conveniently located immediately adjacent to UTC – Southwest Florida’s shopping, dining and entertainment destination. Admission There are no admission or parking fees, except during select special events. Please check our calendar of events for more information. Visitor Map Plan your visit before you arrive or download the map upon your arrival.  Maps are also conveniently located throughout the park.
